tradeIdeas.title: Long Brent Crude / Long ASEAN Energy Producers
tradeIdeas.rationale: Strait of Hormuz effectively closed post-Feb 28 US-Israeli strikes on Iran. Brent surged 13% to $82.37/bbl at peak; now trading $78.22/bbl with sustained geopolitical risk premium. Goldman Sachs models $18/bbl 'Iran shock' add-on; BloombergNEF targets $91/bbl under prolonged disruption. ASEAN energy producers (Petronas-linked, PTT, Medco Energi) benefit directly from price spike. 23% of global LNG trade transits Hormuz — Qatar's 77 mtpa effectively offline. Long near-dated Brent vs short deferred as backwardation steepens. Entry at $78; base target $91, stress target $110.

tradeIdeas.title: Long ASEAN Banks / Short ASEAN Energy Equities
tradeIdeas.rationale: ASEAN Banks index at 218.6 (-0.8 sigma) — selloff overdone for net-oil-exporting names (Maybank, Bangkok Bank) benefiting from MYR/THB carry. ASEAN Energy Equities at 133.5 turning positive on oil spike; prior thesis of falling-oil short now reversed. Recommend unwinding energy equity short leg and rotating into bank long for rate-cut delay beneficiaries. MUFG flags MYR and SGD bank balance sheets as relatively insulated vs PHP/IDR.
instruments: Reduce PTT / Pertamina equity short exposure

tradeIdeas.title: PHP Short — Elevated Conviction on Iran Shock
tradeIdeas.rationale: PHP now most vulnerable ASEAN currency per MUFG (Michael Wan, Mar 2). USD/PHP at 58.09 with DOE warning of immediate fuel price increases (~₱2/liter). >50% of Philippines power generation relies on imported fossil fuels; no strategic LNG reserves. Philippines current account deficit widens to -4.5% of GDP at $90/bbl. BSP rate cut cycle now on hold indefinitely — but IDR and THB also pressured, narrowing yield support. MUFG stress target: 54.50 on sustained oil spike implies near-term risk to 59–60 range. Stop-loss at 57.50.

tradeIdeas.title: IDR Short — Dual Exposure to Iran Shock and Shadow Fleet Risk
tradeIdeas.rationale: IDR at 16,904 (2.2 sigma above 90d avg) and deteriorating. Net oil importer exposed to Hormuz-driven price surge; Bank Indonesia forced into defensive rate hold at 4.75% (Feb 19) despite growth pressure. Indonesia flagged by OFAC and UN for Iranian crude transshipment via Karimun port (18,242 bpd); secondary sanctions enforcement tightening creates financial sector headline risk. Indonesian-branded crude surging into China (~291,000 bpd) potentially covering Iranian origin — OFAC scrutiny risk. Target 17,500–18,000 in stress.

tradeIdeas.title: iTraxx Asia ex-Japan IG CDS Protection — Urgently Widen Target
tradeIdeas.rationale: iTraxx Asia ex-Japan IG exploded to 128bp (+26bp on the day, +5.5 sigma). Iran shock + simultaneous SCS Heightened risk creates dual-front credit deterioration. CDS entered at 102bp; now deep in-the-money. Consider rolling into new 5Y position at 128bp — 180–220bp is credible stress target in 1–3 month Hormuz disruption scenario. ASEAN EM bond outflows and Pertamina/PTT refinancing windows narrowing rapidly.
instruments: Pertamina / PTT bond short via CDS

tradeIdeas.title: Long JKM LNG vs Short TTF — Spread Re-widening on Hormuz Shock
tradeIdeas.rationale: Prior thesis was JKM/TTF convergence (JKM glut vs TTF recovery). Iran shock completely reverses this: JKM has spiked to $14.8/MMBtu (+21.5%) as Asian buyers scramble with Qatar Hormuz supply effectively offline. TTF at €33.5/MWh rising but less acutely. 84% of Hormuz LNG goes to Asia — TTF can source Atlantic Basin LNG. JKM/TTF spread re-widening strongly; in 1-month Hormuz closure scenario both approach $25/MMBtu. Long JKM outright or long JKM vs short TTF spread captures asymmetric Asian supply squeeze.
instruments: Asia LNG spot cargo purchase via intermediary
